In this analysis, we will begin by loading the single-cell RNA-seq data into an AnnData framework, ensuring that quality control parameters are clearly defined—filtering out cells with less than 200 expressed genes or more than 10% mitochondrial gene content—and checking for batch effects if data is derived from multiple sources. We will normalize and log-transform the data, select highly variable genes, and perform PCA (using an appropriate number of components based on dataset complexity) to reduce dimensionality. Using the PCA results, we will construct a k-nearest neighbor graph and apply UMAP for effective visualization, with careful tuning of parameters such as n_neighbors and min_dist. The Leiden clustering algorithm will then be deployed to segment the cellular landscape into distinct clusters; cluster stability will be assessed by exploring different resolution parameters and comparing against alternative methods like Louvain if necessary. Clusters will be characterized through differential expression analysis using the Wilcoxon rank-sum test with appropriate correction for multiple comparisons, while also accounting for covariates linked to tumor progression and recurrence risk. Gene set scoring will be employed to evaluate pathway activities related to cancer progression, inflammation, and extracellular matrix remodeling, with an explicit comparison between tumor samples with and without OSMF. Finally, a suite of visualizations—including annotated UMAP plots, violin plots for key marker genes, and heatmaps—will be generated to ensure that the complex heterogeneity within the OSCC-GB tumor microenvironment is thoroughly characterized, providing valuable biological insights and highlighting potential therapeutic targets.

Differential expression analysis—employing the Wilcoxon rank-sum test with multiple testing corrections—will be performed to delineate marker genes specific to each cluster and to contrast transcriptional differences between OSMF-associated and non-OSMF tumors. This analysis will interrogate single-cell RNA sequencing data from early placental explants exposed to P. falciparum, T. gondii, and L. monocytogenes to reveal the nuanced cell-type-specific transcriptional responses that underpin placental defense mechanisms. A k-nearest neighbors graph will be constructed to support clustering via the Leiden algorithm at multiple resolutions, thereby capturing both broad and nuanced cellular subpopulations, including distinct trophoblast subsets and Hofbauer cells. Subsequent differential expression analyses will compare each pathogen-treated condition against controls within each cell type, with robust FDR corrections and consideration of effect sizes and fold changes to ensure biologically relevant findings. Gene set scoring and pathway enrichment strategies will further elucidate activated immune, stress, and inflammatory pathways, supported by curated gene sets. The proposed analysis begins by loading the human fetal kidney single-cell RNA-seq dataset and rigorously cleaning the data through quality control processes specifically tailored for developmental tissues. This includes setting appropriate thresholds on total counts, number of genes per cell, and mitochondrial read percentages while checking for any batch effects related to different developmental stages or technical runs; if detected, corrections such as Combat or Harmony will be applied. The data will be normalized and log-transformed, and highly variable genes will be selected with a focus on including established kidney developmental markers. PCA will be deployed for reducing dimensionality, with optimal component selection confirmed by elbow plots or explained variance metrics, which in turn will facilitate the construction of a k-nearest neighbor graph. Unsupervised clustering using the Leiden algorithm at multiple resolutions will identify both major cell populations and finer subpopulations, with UMAP visualizations produced for intuitive interpretation. Differential expression analysis using methods like the Wilcoxon rank-sum test will identify markers unique to each cluster, and special attention will be given to the mesenchymal–epithelial transition underlying nephrogenesis. Additionally, cell-cycle scoring and regression will be implemented to minimize confounding effects on trajectory inference. Pseudotime analysis, via diffusion pseudotime (DPT) starting from a progenitor cluster, will elucidate the developmental progression while PAGA graphs will validate the connectivity and branching of lineages, thereby reconstructing the continuum from NPC to PTA, RV, CSB, SSB and distinguishing the nephron epithelial and ureteric bud lineages. This integrated workflow provides a robust framework for unraveling the dynamic and regulated process of human kidney development.

This analysis builds upon initial quality control and clustering by deeply refining cell type definitions within a human fetal kidney scRNA-seq dataset. We will perform sub-clustering of major populations, such as nephron progenitors and ureteric bud-derived cells, at multiple resolutions to accurately capture biological heterogeneity, with validation against established kidney-specific markers. Subsequent differential expression analysis will uncover marker genes that delineate transitional states during the mesenchymal-epithelial transition. A focused cell-cell communication analysis using CellPhoneDB will reveal potential ligand-receptor interactions between critical renal compartments, although these predictions will be interpreted in a correlative context pending further experimental validation. Gene set enrichment analysis with curated kidney developmental gene sets will tie the transcriptomic changes to key signaling pathways like Wnt, FGF, and BMP. Finally, pseudotime trajectory analysis, anchored by a robust selection of progenitor cells, will map the developmental continuum and elucidate the temporal dynamics of signaling interactions. All analyses will be supported by rigorous quality control, batch correction, and statistical validation to ensure the robustness and biological relevance of the findings.

We will initiate our analysis by loading the human fetal kidney single-cell dataset, applying rigorous quality control with thresholds adjusted for the lower RNA content in developing tissue, and comparing batch correction methods such as Harmony and Combat to mitigate technical effects. The data will be normalized, log-transformed, and high-variance genes selected with a focus on kidney developmental markers. Dimensionality reduction via PCA (with explained variance checks) and UMAP will reveal the overall cellular heterogeneity. We will then construct a neighborhood graph and apply the Leiden algorithm to partition the dataset into major renal cell types, validating these with established markers. A refined sub-clustering strategy will target the mesenchymal compartment—specifically tracking nephron progenitors and cells undergoing the mesenchymal-epithelial transition—using marker-guided identification. Trajectory inference through diffusion pseudotime, complemented by PAGA for potential branching, will reconstruct the developmental continuum from progenitors to mature epithelial states. Subsequent differential expression analysis along the pseudotemporal axis, followed by gene set enrichment analysis with curated kidney gene sets, will elucidate the dynamic regulations and signaling pathways underlying nephrogenesis, ensuring each step is statistically robust and biologically validated.

The proposed analysis begins by loading the human fetal kidney scRNA-seq dataset and performing extensive quality control tailored for developmental tissues, including filtering based on total counts, gene numbers, mitochondrial content, and doublet detection using tools like Scrublet or DoubletFinder. After normalization, log-transformation, and selection of highly variable genes focusing on renal developmental markers, dimensionality reduction via PCA and UMAP will reveal cellular heterogeneity. This analysis will rigorously explore the transcriptional dynamics underlying human kidney development by leveraging a human fetal kidney scRNA-seq dataset. After normalization and log-transformation, we will apply PCA and UMAP for dimensionality reduction, ensuring that the developmental gradients are preserved by examining elbow plots and fine-tuning the k-nearest neighbor graph. Clustering with the Leiden algorithm at multiple resolutions, augmented with cell-cycle scoring and regression, will delineate major renal compartments and enable the precise sub-clustering of nephron progenitor and cap mesenchyme populations to resolve intermediate structures such as the pretubular aggregates, renal vesicles, comma-shaped bodies, and s-shaped bodies. Trajectory inference will be performed using diffusion pseudotime—starting from a well-defined progenitor root and validated with PAGA to examine lineage connectivity—while differential expression analysis along the pseudotemporal axis, supported by gene set enrichment analysis, will uncover key regulatory pathways like Wnt, FGF, and BMP that drive the mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition. This stepwise and integrative approach is designed to provide robust biological insights into the molecular mechanisms of human kidney morphogenesis.

This analysis rigorously examines the transcriptional dynamics of human fetal kidney development by leveraging single-cell RNA-seq data through a detailed and iterative computational workflow. We begin by applying stringent quality control measures tailored for low RNA-content tissues, including explorative filtering based on total counts, gene numbers, and mitochondrial percentages, as well as doublet removal and careful batch effect correction using Harmony or Combat. After normalizing and log-transforming the data, we identify highly variable genes with an emphasis on critical kidney developmental markers like SIX2, CITED1, and PAX2 to capture both mesenchymal and emerging epithelial states. Dimensionality reduction using PCA and UMAP—validated through elbow plots and sensitivity analyses—enables robust neighborhood graph construction, which forms the basis for unsupervised clustering via the Leiden algorithm. Multi-resolution clustering, combined with cell-cycle scoring and regression, facilitates precise cluster annotation and sub-clustering, particularly within the nephron progenitor population undergoing the mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition. Differential expression analysis is then applied to uncover marker genes with statistical rigor, followed by trajectory inference using diffusion pseudotime anchored on a progenitor root and validated with PAGA to reconstruct a coherent developmental continuum. Finally, gene signature scoring of key pathways (Wnt, FGF, BMP) is integrated along the pseudotime trajectory, linking functional pathway activity to the observed transcriptional transitions, thereby providing comprehensive insights into the molecular mechanisms orchestrating human kidney morphogenesis.

In this analysis, we will leverage a human fetal kidney scRNA-seq dataset to dissect the complex transcriptional dynamics underlying kidney development. We begin with a rigorous quality control approach that includes filtering out cells based on total counts, gene numbers, mitochondrial read percentages, and doublet detection, while addressing batch effects with a comparative analysis of Harmony and Combat using quantitative benchmarks like the preservation of developmental gradients. Following normalization, log-transformation, and careful selection of highly variable kidney-specific markers—including adjustment for cell-cycle effects—we will reduce the dimensionality of the data using PCA and UMAP. A k-nearest neighbor graph will then be constructed to facilitate unsupervised clustering via the Leiden algorithm, with clusters validated both through established renal markers and hierarchical dendrograms. Our focused sub-clustering within the nephron progenitor compartment aims to capture the continuum of the mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition, allowing us to define intermediate developmental states. Trajectory analysis will be performed using diffusion pseudotime, with PAGA used to validate branching and connectivity, thereby elucidating the continuous progression of cell states from progenitor to mature epithelial cells. Finally, gene signature scoring, coupled with differential expression and gene set enrichment analyses, will be employed to link key signaling pathways such as Wnt, FGF, and BMP to the observed transcriptional dynamics, offering comprehensive insights into the molecular mechanisms orchestrating human kidney morphogenesis.

In this analysis, we propose a detailed computational workflow to elucidate the transcriptional dynamics underpinning human fetal kidney development. We will begin by loading the scRNA-seq dataset and performing rigorous quality control—including the removal of low-quality cells, doublet detection, and careful batch correction using Harmony and Combat—to ensure that the intrinsic developmental gradients are maintained. The data will then be normalized, log-transformed, and subjected to feature selection with an emphasis on known kidney developmental markers. Dimensionality reduction via PCA (supported by elbow plots) and UMAP will visualize cellular heterogeneity and set the stage for constructing a k-nearest neighbor graph. Using this graph, unsupervised clustering with the Leiden algorithm will identify major renal compartments and subtle subpopulations. Special attention will be given to sub-clustering the nephron progenitor compartment to capture the continuum of the mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition, an essential process in nephrogenesis. Differential expression analysis will be employed to validate cluster identities and detect key transitional markers, while trajectory inference through diffusion pseudotime (anchored on specific progenitor clusters) and validated with PAGA will reconstruct the developmental continuum. Finally, by integrating gene signature scoring and gene set enrichment analyses, we will link key signaling pathways (Wnt, FGF, BMP) to the observed transcriptional profiles, offering comprehensive insights into the molecular mechanisms driving human kidney morphogenesis.

The analysis begins with rigorous quality control of the single-cell RNA-seq data, where cells are filtered based on total counts, gene counts, and mitochondrial gene percentages using thresholds determined from distribution analysis. Normalization, log-transformation, and scaling are then applied, followed by dimensionality reduction via PCA. A k-nearest-neighbor graph is constructed based on the top PCs and UMAP is used to visualize the cellular heterogeneity, with special attention given to exploring different clustering resolutions. The Leiden algorithm is employed to delineate cellular subpopulations, particularly focusing on the annotation and validation of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell clusters using known markers and external references. Subsequently, gene signature scoring for IFN-γ and related cytokine signaling pathways is calculated, either on a single-cell level or aggregated within the HSC/HSPC clusters. Differential expression analysis is then conducted, restricting the focus to the HSC/HSPC populations and comparing patients with and without prolonged cytopenia while accounting for potential confounders. The findings are integrated with comprehensive visualizations such as UMAP plots, heatmaps, dotplots, and violin plots, thereby providing robust insights into the molecular mechanisms underpinning prolonged cytopenia in rrLBCL patients following CAR T-cell therapy.

This analysis will investigate the role of dysregulated IFN-γ signaling in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSC/HSPCs) as a key factor driving prolonged cytopenia in rrLBCL patients following CAR T-cell therapy. We begin by ensuring data quality through stringent filtering and normalization steps, then isolate the HSC/HSPC population using canonical markers and external references to ensure accuracy. A k-nearest-neighbor graph constructed from either PCA or SCVI latent embeddings sets the stage for fine sub-clustering via the Leiden algorithm, with adjustments to capture IFN-γ responsiveness nuances. Guided by established markers, a diffusion pseudotime analysis will be conducted from a defined quiescent HSC root to map differentiation trajectories and transitional states. Curated gene signature scores for IFN-γ signaling will be correlated with these trajectories to reflect dynamic pathway activity. Differential expression analysis, controlling for potential batch effects and comparing patients with and without prolonged cytopenia, will pinpoint key regulatory genes and pathways linked to adverse clinical outcomes. Comprehensive visualizations including UMAPs, pseudotime plots, heatmaps, and violin/dot plots will provide an integrative view of how altered IFN-γ signaling affects cellular differentiation and contributes to hematopoietic dysfunction.

The analysis will rigorously explore the contribution of IFN-γ signaling dysregulation to hematopoietic dysfunction following CAR T-cell therapy in rrLBCL patients. It begins with stringent quality control across cells and samples, where inter-sample variability is closely examined and confounding effects such as cell cycle and mitochondrial content are regressed out. The HSC/HSPC compartment will be meticulously isolated using validated markers and external references, ensuring the subset is truly representative. Dimensionality reduction through PCA and SCVI, followed by k-nearest-neighbor graph construction and Leiden clustering (with additional t-SNE validation), will uncover cellular subpopulations. Gene signature scoring, focused on IFN-γ pathways, will be computed and overlaid on the embeddings to identify differential signaling patterns. Using diffusion pseudotime analysis initiated from a biologically informed root cell, the differentiation trajectories will be mapped, with IFN-γ scores correlated against pseudotime to capture dynamic changes. Differential expression analysis will then compare cells from patients with and without prolonged cytopenia, while robust statistical models account for batch effects and inter-donor variability. A suite of visualizations, including UMAP, t-SNE, heatmaps, violin plots, dotplots, and connectivity analyses like dendrograms or PAGA, will integrate the findings, ultimately clarifying the role of altered IFN-γ signaling in driving hematopoietic defects.

This analysis is designed to elucidate the impact of dysregulated IFN-γ signaling on hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell (HSC/HSPC) differentiation in rrLBCL patients experiencing prolonged cytopenia after CAR T-cell therapy. The workflow starts with an extensive quality control process that filters cells based on total counts, gene counts, and mitochondrial gene content, and incorporates doublet detection to ensure data integrity. Normalization, log-transformation, and scaling are then performed, with confounders such as cell cycle effects regressed out and batch correction applied as needed to mitigate technical variability. The HSC/HSPC population is identified and validated using canonical surface markers supported by literature and external datasets. Dimensionality reduction via PCA and, optionally, SCVI latent embeddings sets the stage for constructing a robust k-nearest-neighbor graph, followed by refined clustering using the Leiden algorithm with multiple resolutions to capture IFN-γ–responsive subpopulations. Diffusion pseudotime analysis is employed from a biologically defined quiescent HSC root to map cellular development trajectories, with IFN-γ gene signature scores overlaid and statistically correlated with pseudotime. Differential expression analysis within the HSC/HSPC clusters then compares cells from patients with and without prolonged cytopenia, accounting for batch and patient-specific variabilities. A comprehensive suite of visualizations, including UMAPs, pseudotime plots, heatmaps, and violin/dot plots, integrates these findings to provide a detailed understanding of the molecular mechanisms by which dysregulated IFN-γ signaling contributes to hematopoietic dysfunction in this clinical context.

This analysis aims to elucidate the role of dysregulated IFN-γ signaling within HSC/HSPCs in rrLBCL patients with prolonged cytopenia after CAR T-cell therapy. We begin by performing an extensive quality control on the scRNA-seq dataset—filtering based on gene counts, mitochondrial content, and detecting doublets—to ensure high data integrity, while also accounting for batch and cell cycle effects. Following normalization and scaling of the data, we reduce dimensionality using PCA or potentially SCVI latent embeddings to construct a robust k-nearest-neighbor graph. UMAP visualization combined with Leiden clustering, guided by canonical markers and external references, will allow us to accurately define the HSC/HSPC compartment. Subsequent gene signature scoring for IFN-γ will highlight pathway-active subpopulations. A diffusion pseudotime analysis, initiated from a well-supported quiescent HSC, will be employed to map differentiation trajectories and explore dynamic changes in IFN-γ signaling along these trajectories. Differential expression analysis, carefully controlling for confounders across clusters or the entire compartment, will pinpoint key transcriptional changes associated with prolonged cytopenia. Finally, comprehensive visualizations will integrate these multi-layered findings, providing a detailed view of the mechanisms by which altered IFN-γ signaling might impair hematopoietic differentiation and contribute to the clinical phenotype observed in these patients.

Finally, a suite of integrative visualizations—including UMAP, pseudotime plots, heatmaps, violin plots, and dot plots—will synthesize these findings, providing a comprehensive view of how altered IFN-γ signaling could impair hematopoiesis and lead to persistent cytopenia in this clinical context.

This analysis is designed to elucidate the mechanistic role of dysregulated IFN-γ signaling in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and its impact on prolonged cytopenia in rrLBCL patients following CAR T-cell therapy. The workflow starts with rigorous quality control, filtering out low-quality cells based on total counts, mitochondrial content, and doublet detection, while carefully regressing out confounders such as cell cycle effects—using hematopoietic-specific markers—and batch variations. In this analysis, we will systematically explore the single-cell transcriptomic landscape of Crohn's disease by first loading and preprocessing scRNA-seq data from both ileal and colonic biopsies. Rigorous quality control procedures will be implemented, filtering cells based on mitochondrial gene percentage and overall gene counts—with thresholds determined from distribution plots—and potential batch effects will be identified and corrected using patient metadata. We will then conduct dimensionality reduction using PCA followed by UMAP to visualize cellular heterogeneity, carefully comparing inflamed versus non-inflamed regions and across anatomical sites. A neighborhood graph will be constructed from PCA embeddings to support the application of the Leiden clustering algorithm, with cluster resolution optimized to capture meaningful cell subpopulations and validated using established marker genes. Differential expression analysis will be performed both between clusters and within the same tissue types to capture markers and pathways linked to disease pathology, using robust statistical tests and FDR correction. Furthermore, gene set scoring will quantify the activity of immune and epithelial barrier pathways using validated gene lists, while augmented metadata analyses will ensure consideration of inter-patient variability. Finally, results will be integrated and visualized through heatmaps, dotplots, and annotated UMAP plots that highlight tissue type, inflammation status, and patient identity, thus elucidating the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving site-specific disease processes in Crohn's disease.

The analysis will initiate by loading scRNA-seq data from ileal and colonic biopsies of Crohn's disease patients, followed by rigorous quality control that employs distribution plots to determine thresholds for mitochondrial gene percentage and total gene counts, along with additional screening for doublets and ambient RNA. Batch effects will be addressed using patient metadata and, if needed, advanced integration techniques such as Harmony or ComBat. After normalization and scaling, principal component analysis (PCA) will be performed, with a careful review of explained variance to guide the selection of PCs for downstream analysis. A UMAP embedding will then be generated to visualize cellular heterogeneity across inflamed and non-inflamed tissues and between anatomical sites. A k-nearest neighbor graph will be constructed with mandatory parameter settings, and the Leiden clustering algorithm will be applied with iterative optimization of resolution to ensure biologically meaningful clusters. Differential expression analysis using the Wilcoxon rank-sum test with FDR correction will identify key marker genes, which will be cross-referenced against known IBD risk genes and signatures. Finally, gene signature scoring for pathways related to immune responses and epithelial barrier function will be performed using established methods, and the results will be visualized via annotated UMAPs, heatmaps, and dot plots to integrate insights from batch metadata and provide a comprehensive picture of disease-specific cellular mechanisms.

The analysis begins by importing and annotating scRNA-seq data from ileal and colonic biopsies of Crohn’s disease patients, carefully distinguishing inflamed from non-inflamed tissues and incorporating patient metadata for downstream corrections. Gene signature scoring is performed to quantify pathways related to epithelial integrity, microbial sensing, and immune regulation by applying validated gene sets. This analysis begins by loading scRNA-seq datasets from healthy and carious dental pulp tissues, performing extensive quality control tailored to dental pulp biology to filter out low-quality cells and potential doublets. The proposed analysis will begin with meticulous preprocessing of the scRNA-seq data derived from the human embryonic neural tube, emphasizing quality control, normalization, and batch integration if necessary. For trajectory analysis, diffusion pseudotime will be utilized with a defined root cell population (basal cells) to reconstruct the differentiation pathway, supplemented with branching analysis to explore the possibility of secretory to ciliated cell conversion. Finally, gene set scoring will be used to evaluate the activation of ciliogenesis-related pathways, and an array of visualizations including UMAP plots, heatmaps, and dot plots will be generated to integrate and validate the findings. This comprehensive approach is designed to illuminate the molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced differentiation of ciliated cells in ALI cultures.

In this analysis, we begin by loading the scRNA-seq dataset from cystic fibrosis lung tissue and rigorously filtering the data to retain only high-quality cells, with particular attention to potential donor-specific batch effects. After normalizing and log-transforming the data, we scale it and perform PCA to reduce dimensionality, building a kNN graph that underpins our UMAP visualizations. We cluster cells using the Leiden algorithm, effectively segregating epithelial and immune populations. Differential expression analysis is employed to detect both novel markers and established CF-related genes (like CFTR), providing insights into chronic inflammation, impaired repair, and immune dysregulation. Additionally, we score cells using curated gene sets connected to inflammatory signaling, epithelial repair, tissue remodeling, and immune dysregulation, allowing a detailed examination of the disrupted epithelial-immune crosstalk in CF. Comprehensive visualizations, including UMAP plots, dot plots, heatmaps, and violin plots, are generated to integrate and convey the cellular heterogeneity and functional phenotypes that underlie CF pathology, ultimately paving the way to identify novel therapeutic targets.

The analysis starts by loading scRNA-seq data from cystic fibrosis lung tissue while rigorously performing quality control by documenting and filtering based on metrics such as mitochondrial gene percentage, total counts, and number of genes per cell. This systematic approach bridges rigorous data processing with biologically focused analyses to provide insights that could inform new therapeutic strategies.

Dimensionality reduction via PCA followed by a k-nearest neighbor graph will set the stage for UMAP visualizations that provide a global view of cellular heterogeneity. These clusters will be annotated using canonical marker genes through a combination of automated and manual approaches. Differential expression analysis—supported by rigorous statistical testing and gene signature scoring for inflammatory and cytokine pathways, including IL1-RA—will clarify how the two conditions differ at the molecular level. Lastly, a suite of detailed visualizations will effectively communicate the differences in immune profiles and validate our hypothesis regarding distinct inflammatory responses in SARS-CoV-2 versus vaccine-associated myocarditis.

The analysis will begin by importing the cardiac single-cell RNA-seq dataset into an AnnData object, ensuring adherence to data type by focusing exclusively on RNA measurements. Rigorous quality control will be implemented by filtering cells based on defined thresholds such as <200 genes per cell and >10-15% mitochondrial gene content, validated via QC visualizations. Following log transformation normalization and scaling, dimensionality reduction will be achieved through PCA, with an option to use scVI for a more refined latent embedding that enhances batch correction and uncovers subtle biological signals. A k-nearest neighbor graph will be constructed using the selected embedding, and UMAP will be used to visualize the cellular landscape while overlaying metadata to verify integration success. Clustering via the Leiden algorithm will then be utilized to identify distinct cell populations, with a particular focus on immune cells like macrophages and cytotoxic lymphocytes, validated by canonical marker expression and potential sub-clustering. Differential expression analysis within these key clusters, employing robust statistical methodologies and multiple testing corrections, will pinpoint inflammatory and cytokine-related markers—especially IL1-RA—differentiating SARS-CoV-2 and mRNA vaccine-associated myocarditis. Complementary gene signature scoring will further quantify inflammatory pathway activity, and optional receptor–ligand analysis will provide insights into cell-cell communication dynamics. A suite of comprehensive visualizations will be generated to support the findings, thereby offering a robust dissection of the distinct immunological responses driving these two forms of myocarditis.

In this analysis, we will begin by importing the cardiac single-cell RNA-seq data into an AnnData object, applying extensive quality control measures—filtering cells for low gene counts, high mitochondrial and ribosomal content, and removing potential doublets—to ensure a robust and high-quality dataset. Dimensionality reduction through PCA (or the scVI latent space) will be followed by constructing a k-nearest neighbor graph, leading into the generation of UMAP visualizations that are conditionally annotated. Utilizing the Leiden algorithm, we will delineate cellular subpopulations and further refine the clustering by subsetting key immune cells—particularly macrophages—using canonical markers. A trajectory or pseudotime analysis (for example, diffusion pseudotime) will then be employed to explore continuous activation states within these immune cells. Differential expression analysis will identify key inflammatory and cytokine markers, including IL1-RA, that distinguish the two myocarditis forms, which will be supplemented by gene signature scoring to quantify inflammatory pathway activities. Finally, a comprehensive suite of visualizations, including UMAP overlays, dotplots, heatmaps, violin plots, and trajectory plots, will be generated to robustly communicate the unique immunological landscapes underlying these inflammatory cardiomyopathies.

In this analysis, we will build a comprehensive cellular atlas of the human retina by integrating single-cell transcriptomic and epigenomic data. The process begins with meticulous quality control and normalization tailored to the retinal tissue—employing specific thresholds for mitochondrial content in RNA-seq and fragment counts/TSS enrichment in ATAC-seq. We will perform dimensionality reduction using both PCA and advanced latent embedding methods (such as scVI) to reliably capture cellular heterogeneity, followed by the construction of a k-nearest neighbor graph and application of Leiden clustering with optimized parameters. This enables the identification and annotation of major retinal cell types and the resolution of rare subpopulations, including distinct retinal ganglion cells. Simultaneously, the ATAC-seq data will be analyzed through peak calling (using MACS2), motif enrichment (with chromVAR), and linking of accessible chromatin regions to nearby genes via both distance and correlation-based methods (like Cicero). Integration of the transcriptomic and epigenomic layers will be accomplished through co-embedding and correlation analysis, thereby revealing cell-type-specific regulatory elements. The analysis will incorporate rigorous differential expression and statistical validation (including permutation tests) to ensure robustness, and results will be visualized using UMAP embeddings, heatmaps, and dot plots that clearly depict the interplay between gene expression and regulatory activity across the retinal cellular landscape.

This analysis will generate a high-resolution atlas of the human retina by integrating snRNA-seq and scATAC-seq data with a robust computational pipeline designed to capture the full cellular heterogeneity of the retina, including rare cell types. We will begin with stringent quality control tailored to retinal tissue, utilizing clear threshold criteria and visualization methods to ensure that key metrics such as mitochondrial content, fragment counts, and TSS enrichment are accurately assessed. Dimensionality reduction will be performed separately on the gene expression and chromatin accessibility data using PCA/UMAP and LSI respectively, and batch effects will be addressed using methods like Harmony when necessary. Unsupervised clustering with the Leiden algorithm at multiple resolutions will enable the identification of both major cell types and rare subpopulations, with cluster identities validated against established retinal markers. Differential expression and peak calling analyses will link transcriptomic and epigenomic determinants through both correlation and distance-based approaches, while integrated co-embedding of both modalities coupled with motif enrichment analysis will elucidate the regulatory networks driving retinal diversity. Finally, rigorous statistical validation combined with diverse visualization strategies will ensure the reliability and interpretability of the resulting atlas, providing novel insights into retinal biology and disease mechanisms.

The analysis will start by performing stringent, retinal-tailored quality control and normalization on both scRNA-seq and scATAC-seq datasets, using thresholds informed by pilot data and providing rich QC plots to identify potential outliers. Independent k-nearest neighbor graphs and multi-resolution Leiden clustering will identify major retinal cell types as well as rare subpopulations, with cluster identities validated against established markers. Integration will involve linking open chromatin peaks to nearby gene expression through both distance and correlation approaches, augmented by computing gene activity scores, and then aligning latent spaces via techniques like mutual nearest neighbors. Differential analyses including differential expression and differential accessibility, accompanied by motif enrichment, will shed light on the regulatory networks within the retina, with all tests refined using appropriate multiple testing corrections and validation strategies. Comprehensive visualizations including UMAP embeddings, dot plots, and heatmaps will ensure that the final integrated atlas is both robust and immediately interpretable, setting a strong foundation for further analyses such as network inference or exploration of disease-associated variants.

In this analysis, we first import single-cell RNA and ATAC datasets from human retinal tissue, applying stringent and empirically justified, tissue-specific QC measures along with appropriate normalization protocols such as log-normalization/SCTransform for the RNA data and TF-IDF for ATAC data. We reduce the dimensionality of each dataset using PCA or advanced latent embeddings like scVI (for transcriptomics) and LSI (for epigenomics), while addressing technical variation through batch correction methods like Harmony. We then construct k-nearest neighbor graphs from these embeddings and perform unsupervised clustering using the Leiden algorithm at multiple resolutions, enabling the delineation of both major retinal cell classes and rare neuronal subpopulations. Differential expression and differential chromatin accessibility analyses—enhanced by motif enrichment and gene activity scoring—are conducted to identify key regulatory elements and genes that drive cell-type-specific functions. Finally, we integrate the two modalities using co-embedding and mutual nearest neighbor strategies, linking chromatin accessibility to gene expression patterns. Rigorous statistical validations and comprehensive visualizations culminate in a high-resolution atlas of the human retina, offering deep insights into its cellular heterogeneity and regulatory landscape related to retinal disorders.

The analysis will start by meticulously preprocessing snRNA-seq data obtained from the MTG of five primate species. Emphasis will be placed on quality control, normalization, and batch correction, with a critical ortholog mapping step to align gene identities across species. Dimensionality reduction via PCA followed by UMAP will allow us to visualize global cellular heterogeneity while confirming the presence of known cell type markers. A k-nearest-neighbor graph will then be built for clustering using the Leiden algorithm, exploring multiple clustering resolutions and employing hierarchical methods to capture finer cell subpopulations. After clusters are annotated using canonical and publicly validated cell type markers, a focused differential expression analysis will compare human clusters with those from nonhuman primates, controlling for multiple testing. Gene set enrichment analyses, using gene sets pertinent to language and cognitive functions, will provide mechanistic insights into the observed differences. Finally, comprehensive visualizations—including heatmaps, dotplots, and violin plots—will be used to construct an integrated comparative cellular atlas that elucidates both conserved and human-specific molecular traits in the MTG.

This analysis begins with loading the single-cell RNA-seq data from human thymocytes, followed by stringent quality control measures that include filtering based on mitochondrial content, gene counts, and detection of doublets to ensure the data represents single cells. This analysis starts with a rigorous, donor-specific quality control pipeline where thresholds for UMI counts, gene detection, and mitochondrial gene percentages are carefully determined and documented, alongside doublet detection via Scrublet cross-validated with mutually exclusive marker expression to safeguard against discarding rare populations. Exploratory data analysis using both PCA and scVI latent embeddings will be performed, with UMAP visualizations and quantitative metrics (such as silhouette scores) used to assess and compare batch-correction strategies. Integrated data will then be used to build a k-nearest neighbor graph that underpins Leiden clustering, with careful parameter justification to accurately capture the complex cellular landscape of pancreatic islets. Cluster annotation will rely on canonical markers and be validated through module scoring, setting the stage for cell type–specific differential expression analyses that, using robust statistical models accounting for donor variability, will pinpoint key genes disrupted in T2D. A focused ligand-receptor analysis, leveraging a rigorously curated, pancreas-specific database with defined minimal expression thresholds, will elucidate altered intercellular signaling—especially the paracrine communications impacting beta cell insulin secretion. Optionally, pseudotime analysis may further reveal dedifferentiation trajectories within beta cells. A suite of detailed visualizations will provide an integrated view of quality control, clustering, gene expression, and network disruption, leading to biologically meaningful insights into T2D pathology.

The analysis is designed to dissect the impact of intrinsic aging on fibroblast subpopulations in sun-protected human skin by leveraging single-cell RNA-seq data. The workflow begins with comprehensive quality control measures including filtering based on gene counts, mitochondrial, ribosomal, and hemoglobin gene content, as well as doublet detection to eliminate cell multiplets. Next, the data is normalized using scRNA-seq-specific approaches and scaled, followed by PCA to reduce dimensionality—validated by an elbow plot to ensure optimum component selection. A k-nearest neighbors graph is built from the PCA-reduced data, with careful tuning of neighbor parameters, and UMAP is used to generate a visually interpretable low-dimensional embedding. Clustering is performed using the Leiden algorithm, and clusters are annotated using well-established markers that distinguish papillary from reticular fibroblasts. Differential expression analysis is then carried out within these annotated fibroblast populations with special consideration given to age as a covariate, ensuring that intrinsic aging-related transcriptomic changes are statistically and biologically validated. The results are presented through a suite of visualizations including UMAP plots, violin plots with statistical annotations, and heatmaps, thereby providing a detailed framework to unravel the molecular underpinnings of skin aging.

Differential expression analysis, incorporating age as a continuous variable and adjusting for potential confounders, will be used to identify age-associated transcriptional changes. Complementing this, gene signature scoring based on established gene sets will quantify the status of ECM remodeling, senescence, and immune responses. The outcomes of the analysis will be visually represented via UMAP overlays, violin plots, heatmaps, and regression plots, collectively providing a comprehensive picture of the molecular alterations induced by intrinsic skin aging.

In this analysis, we will start by loading and rigorously quality controlling the single-cell RNA-seq data obtained from human quadriceps tendons following acute rupture. Quality control will include not only standard metrics such as total counts, gene detection, and mitochondrial content, but also doublet removal using Scrublet and an assessment for batch effects to ensure clean data for downstream analysis. We will normalize the data and select highly variable features, then perform PCA and UMAP-based dimensionality reduction after constructing a k-nearest neighbors graph, with parameter optimizations to accommodate the low cellularity of tendon tissue. Clustering will be performed using the Leiden algorithm, and clusters will be annotated using confirmed tendon cell markers to precisely identify fibroblast (tenocyte), endothelial, and immune cell populations. Differential expression analysis, with proper multiple testing corrections, will be employed to pinpoint unique genes associated with fibroblast activation and inflammation. Additionally, we will score gene signatures related to ECM remodeling and inflammatory pathways to further validate our findings. If the data indicate continuous fibroblast transitions, a pseudotime analysis will be conducted to elucidate the dynamics of early repair. Finally, results will be visualized using UMAP plots, violin plots, heatmaps, and dot plots to clearly illustrate the distinct transcriptional changes driving tendon repair processes.
